ground_truth: The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume, opening it. It's huge and there's a lot to go through, and the print itself makes him squint. The book shows TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded, but in the owners' column, there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners. The Clerk turns sharply around, and Gittes looks a little surprised. The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, and slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler, opens the book, and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves, and narrower roads, Gittes parks at the edge of the field. He is hefted half off the ground by two younger Farmers who spin him around, going through his clothes, tossing his wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet, with his back to the Red Faced Farmer, leaning against the back of his car, breathing heavily. The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch, causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The paper's on the ground, and he picks it up. The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes, who kicks him squarely in the nuts, knees him in the jaw after he's doubled up, and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head, knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt. Gittes is staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the farmers, with his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and the dog present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a huge mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn is driving, and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case, takes one, and offers one to Evelyn, who refuses. It's almost evening. He pulls out the obituary column he'd folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The Employee turns away quickly and pulls down the northwest valley tome, opening it. It's enormous and there's much to go through, and the type itself makes him squint. The tome shows TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is lengthy and hopelessly intricate, with descriptions like '6000 steps to Rio Seco, thence 7000 steps to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are ancient and faded, but in the proprietors' column, there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the previous proprietors. The Employee turns sharply around, and Gittes looks a little startled. The aggravated Employee reaches around, rummages, and slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler, opens the tome, and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, he places the ruler, looks toward the employees, then quickly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the proprietor's name and property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or coughs to mask the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying orchards, and narrower roads, Gittes parks at the edge of the field. He is lifted half off the ground by two younger Agriculturists who spin him around, going through his garments, tossing his billfold, his silver cigarette case, etc. Gittes is badly battered and half out on his feet, with his back to the Red Faced Agriculturist, leaning against the back of his vehicle, breathing heavily. The Crippled Agriculturist pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch, causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Agriculturist. The paper's on the ground, and he picks it up. The Big Agriculturist takes a swing at Gittes, who kicks him squarely in the groin, knees him in the jaw after he's doubled over, and punches him solidly. The Crippled Agriculturist takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head, knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Agriculturist who is writhing in agony in the dirt. Gittes is staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the agriculturists, with his wife, the Red Faced Agriculturist, the Big Agriculturist, and the dog present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a huge bruise on his cheek, and his garments are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn is driving, and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case, takes one, and offers one to Evelyn, who declines. It's almost evening. He pulls out the obituary column he'd folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The northwest valley volume is hauled down abruptly by the Clerk, and it is opened by him. It is huge and there is a lot to go through, and he is made to squint by the print itself. TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation are shown in the book where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded, but numerous freshly typed names are pasted over the prior owners in the owners' column. The Clerk turns sharply around, a little surprise is shown by Gittes. The desk is slapped by the exasperated Clerk after he rummages around. The stacks are returned to by Gittes with the ruler, and the book is opened by him, placing the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, and then a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description is swiftly torn down by him, with the sound of the paper being ripped covered by either a sniffle or cough. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves, and narrower roads, the edge of the field is where Gittes is parked. He hefts two younger Farmers half off the ground, spins them around while going through his clothes, tossing his wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. The Red Faced Farmer has his back leaned against by Gittes, who is badly banged up and half out on his feet, breathing heavily. Gittes is rudely poked in the back with a crutch by the Crippled Farmer, causing him to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The paper is on the ground, and it is picked up by him. A swing is taken at Gittes by the Big Farmer, who is kicked squarely in the nuts, kneed in the jaw after he doubles up, and hit solidly by Gittes. Careful aim is taken by the Crippled Farmer, and Gittes' head is brought down with the crutch, knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Farmer writhing in agony in the dirt. The screened-in porch of the farmers is stared down at by Gittes while lying there, with his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and the dog present. Dried blood is seen down the side of his face from his nose, a huge mouse is on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn drives, and the cigarette case is pulled out by Gittes, who takes one and offers one to Evelyn, who refuses. It is almost evening. The obituary column he'd folded up earlier in the day is pulled out by him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The Clerk abruptly turns, grabs the northwest valley volume, and opens it. The book is massive and detailed, and the print makes him squint. It lists TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even METES AND BOUNDS with long, intricate descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, then 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' Although old and faded, the owners' column has freshly typed names pasted over previous ones. The Clerk sharply turns, surprising Gittes, and slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes returns to the stacks, places the ruler vertically beside the OWNER column, and swiftly tears out a strip about two inches wide, covering the sound by sniffing or coughing. Amid shimmering dust and parched groves, Gittes parks at the field's edge. Two younger Farmers search him, tossing his wallet and cigarette case. Battered and exhausted, he leans against his car as the Crippled Farmer pokes him with a crutch, making him turn to the Red Faced Farmer. He picks up the torn paper, and when the Big Farmer swings, Gittes kicks and knees him, then hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer targets Gittes' head with his crutch, knocking him down beside the writhing Big Farmer. On the screened porch with his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and a dog, Gittes lies with dried blood on his face, a swollen cheek, and torn clothes, remaining silent. In the evening, Evelyn drives while Gittes pulls out his cigarette case, offering one to Evelyn, who declines, and unfolds the obituary column he kept earlier.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The Clerk abruptly retrieves the northwest valley volume and opens it. The book is large and densely printed, requiring him to squint. It includes terms like TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and METES AND BOUNDS for land descriptions, which are long and outdated. In the owner's column, new names are pasted over old ones. The Clerk, exasperated, hands Gittes a ruler. Gittes returns to the stacks, opens the book, and places the ruler vertically beside the OWNER column, tearing out a strip containing the owner's name. He covers the ripping sound with a sniffle. In a dusty, heat-filled area near dry groves, Gittes parks, only to be accosted by two young Farmers who search him and throw his belongings aside. Battered and weak, he leans against his car. The Crippled Farmer prods him with a crutch, prompting him to face the Red Faced Farmer. Gittes retrieves a paper from the ground. The Big Farmer attacks, but Gittes counters, causing pain. The Crippled Farmer then knocks Gittes out with a crutch. Lying on the screened-in porch with dried blood and torn clothes, Gittes remains silent among the farmers and a dog. Later, Evelyn drives, and Gittes offers her a cigarette from his case, which she declines. Near evening, he unfolds the obituary column from earlier.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The Clerk, with a sudden and abrupt motion, turns away and reaches up to haul down the large volume dedicated to the northwest valley, quickly opening it. This massive book, filled with an overwhelming amount of information to sift through, causes him to squint due to the minuscule print. Within its pages, the book meticulously details TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation. The description of the land parcel is extensive and complicated, with intricate descriptions such as '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions, though valuable, appear old and faded; however, in the owners' column, numerous freshly typed names are pasted conspicuously over the names of the prior owners. The Clerk, now visibly exasperated, turns sharply around, catching Gittes by surprise. Reaching around in a hurried manner, the Clerk rummages through the desk and slaps a ruler down with a decisive gesture. Gittes returns to the stacks with the ruler in hand, reopens the sizable book, and places the ruler not horizontally, as one might expect, but instead positions it vertically. He carefully aligns the ruler beside the OWNER column, glances discreetly toward the clerks, and then deftly tears down the page, removing a strip about two inches wide that contains critical information: the owner's name and property description. As he executes this maneuver, he either sniffles or coughs to cleverly mask the sound of the paper being stealthily ripped. Amidst an expanse marked by shimmering dust, intense heat, parched, drying groves, and narrower, winding roads, Gittes parks precariously at the edge of a vast field. Suddenly, he is hefted off the ground by two younger Farmers, who spin him around unceremoniously, rifling through his clothes, casually tossing aside his wallet, his silver cigarette case, and other personal items. Badly banged up and barely able to remain on his feet, Gittes finds himself leaning heavily against the back of his car, breathing laboriously with his back to the Red Faced Farmer. The Crippled Farmer rudely jabs him in the back with his crutch, prompting Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The piece of paper lies neglected on the ground, and he bends down to pick it up. The Big Farmer takes an aggressive swing at Gittes, who reacts swiftly by kicking him squarely in a sensitive area, then knees him in the jaw as the Farmer doubles over, delivering a solid blow. Observing the scene with precision, the Crippled Farmer carefully aims and brings his crutch down with force on the back of Gittes' head, sending him crashing to the ground. Gittes lies motionless beside the Big Farmer, who writhes in agony amidst the dirt. Gittes, now recovering, finds himself staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the farmers. Present are his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and a dog. Blood has dried along the side of his face from his nose, a conspicuous bruise swells on his cheek, and his clothes are visibly torn in a couple of places. He gazes out silently, saying nothing. Later, as Evelyn drives, Gittes retrieves his cigarette case, removes a cigarette, and extends the offer to Evelyn, who politely declines. As the day draws to a close, nearing evening, he pulls out the obituary column he had neatly folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: In a sudden and abrupt motion, the Clerk spins around and reaches up with purpose to take down the large, hefty volume dedicated specifically to the northwest valley, quickly flipping it open with a practiced hand. This enormous book, brimming with an overwhelming amount of information to sift through, causes him some strain as he squints due to the minuscule, cramped print on the pages. Within these pages, the book meticulously and painstakingly details TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even provides a METES AND BOUNDS designation. The description of the land parcel is both extensive and complicated, with intricate descriptions that include phrases such as '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, and so on.' These descriptions, while valuable and crucial, appear old and faded; however, in the column designated for the owners, numerous freshly typed names are conspicuously and prominently pasted over the names of the prior, former owners. The Clerk, now visibly exasperated, turns around sharply, catching Gittes by surprise with the unexpected movement. Fumbling in a hurried manner, the Clerk rummages through the cluttered desk and, with a decisive gesture, slaps a ruler down. Gittes takes the ruler back to the stacks with him, reopens the hefty, sizable book, and strategically places the ruler—not horizontally, as one might expect, but instead aligns it vertically. He carefully aligns the ruler beside the OWNER column, casting a discreet glance toward the clerks, then deftly tears down the page, removing a strip about two inches wide that contains crucial information: the owner's name and property description. As he executes this maneuver, he either sniffles or coughs to cleverly mask the sound of the paper being stealthily ripped apart. Amidst an expansive scene marked by shimmering dust, oppressive and intense heat, parched and drying groves, and narrower, winding roads, Gittes parks rather precariously at the very edge of a vast, open field. Suddenly, he finds himself lifted off the ground by two younger Farmers who unceremoniously spin him around, rifling through his clothes and casually tossing aside his wallet, his prized silver cigarette case, and various other personal items. Badly battered and barely able to stand, Gittes finds himself leaning heavily against the back of his car, struggling to breathe as he faces away from the Red Faced Farmer. The Crippled Farmer rudely jabs him in the back with his crutch, prompting Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The piece of paper lies neglected on the dry ground, and he bends down to pick it up. The Big Farmer, in response, takes an aggressive swing at Gittes, who reacts with quick reflexes by kicking him squarely in a sensitive area, then knees him in the jaw as the Farmer bends over in pain, delivering a solid blow. Observing the unfolding scene with precision, the Crippled Farmer aims carefully and brings his crutch down with force on the back of Gittes' head, sending him crashing heavily to the ground. Gittes lies motionless beside the Big Farmer, who writhes in agony amidst the dirt. As Gittes begins to recover, he finds himself staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the farmers. Present are his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and a dog. Blood has dried along the side of his face from his nose, a conspicuous bruise swells on his cheek, and his clothes are visibly torn and ragged in a couple of places. He stares out silently, saying nothing. Later on, as Evelyn drives, Gittes retrieves his cigarette case, removes a cigarette, and extends the offer to Evelyn, who politely declines. As the day draws to a close, nearing the evening, he pulls out the obituary column he had folded up neatly earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The Clerk, caught in a sudden flurry of motion, pivots away swiftly to seize the northwest valley volume, hauling the hefty tome down from its place before prying it open with meticulous care. Upon opening it, the sheer magnitude of the book unfolds before him, with an overwhelming amount of information sprawling across its pages. The tiny print strains his eyes, forcing him to squint to make sense of it all. As he peruses the contents, the book reveals detailed listings including TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even an intricate METES AND BOUNDS designation, where the land parcel descriptions are extensive and almost unfathomably complex, featuring archaic directions such as '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' Despite their ancient and faded appearance, the owners' column contrasts sharply with the presence of numerous freshly typed names pasted over the old owners, marking a clear distinction between past and present. With a brisk and decisive motion, the Clerk abruptly turns back around, causing Gittes to react with a flicker of surprise at his sudden movement. The Clerk, visibly impatient, reaches around the desk, rummaging through his surroundings until he locates a ruler, which he slams down emphatically onto the desk. Gittes, understanding the unspoken instructions, retrieves the ruler and returns to the stacks. He reopens the book and positions the ruler vertically alongside the OWNER column, ensuring its alignment with precision before casting a quick glance toward the clerks. In one swift and calculating motion, he tears down the page, extracting a narrow strip approximately two inches wide that encapsulates both the owner's name and the property description. To mask the sound of the paper tearing, he discreetly either sniffs or coughs. In a separate scene bathed in shimmering dust and escalating heat, Gittes finds himself amid parched, drying groves and narrowing roads, where he parks at the field's edge. From there, two younger Farmers, exerting their combined strength, hoist him partially off the ground and spin him around forcibly, rifling through his clothes with little regard, scattering his belongings, including his wallet and a silver cigarette case. Gittes, now significantly battered and teetering on the brink of consciousness, props himself against the rear of his car, breathing heavily as he faces away from the Red Faced Farmer. The Crippled Farmer, with calculated rudeness, jabs him in the back with his crutch, compelling Gittes to turn abruptly and meet the gaze of the Red Faced Farmer. Spotting the paper on the ground, he bends down to retrieve it, only to face an unexpected assault as the Big Farmer takes a swing at him. Reacting swiftly, Gittes retaliates by delivering a precise kick that lands squarely in the Big Farmer's groin, doubling him over, followed by a knee to the jaw and a solid punch. In response, the Crippled Farmer takes aim and delivers a decisive blow to the back of Gittes' head with his crutch, sending him crashing to the ground, where he lies motionless beside the Big Farmer, who writhes in agony in the dirt. Gittes, now in a state of dazed contemplation, finds himself lying on the screened-in porch of the farmers' house, surrounded by the Farmer's wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and a dog. Blood has dried along the side of his face, and a large swelling mars his cheek, with his clothes torn in several places. He gazes outward but remains silent. Transitioning to a quieter moment, Evelyn is driving while Gittes retrieves his cigarette case, deftly selecting one cigarette before extending an offer to Evelyn, who declines. As the sky fades toward evening, he unfurls the obituary column he had folded away earlier that day, lost in thought as the car continues its journey.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The Clerk abruptly retrieves and opens the northwest valley volume, laboriously reviewing its detailed land descriptions and noting the freshly updated ownership records. Surprised by the Clerk's abrupt movement, Gittes follows directions to the stacks with a ruler, strategically using it to tear out a strip of the page containing crucial ownership details while masking the sound with a cough. Against a backdrop of shimmering dust and heat, Gittes parks near a field, where he is accosted by two young Farmers who search him, discarding his wallet and belongings. Bruised and exhausted, Gittes, leaning against his car, confronts the Red Faced Farmer after the Crippled Farmer rudely pokes him with a crutch. Tension escalates as Gittes retaliates against an attack by the Big Farmer, resulting in a scuffle where both end up on the ground, Gittes rendered unconscious by a blow from the Crippled Farmer. Later, Gittes lies injured in the farmers' screened-in porch with dried blood and torn clothes, silently observing his surroundings. In the evening, while driving with Evelyn, Gittes retrieves his cigarette case, offering a cigarette to Evelyn, who declines, and unfolds the obituary column he had taken earlier.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The Clerk, a meticulous man known for his attention to detail in the records office, turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume, opening it with a practiced motion. It's huge, a historical tome of land records, and there's a lot to go through, and the print itself makes him squint due to its age and the dim lighting in the archives. The book shows TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation, an old surveying method used before modern mapping, where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded, reflecting the changing landscape over decades, but in the owners' column, there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners, indicating a recent flurry of land transactions. The Clerk turns sharply around, and Gittes, known in town for his investigative persistence, looks a little surprised. The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, and slaps a ruler on the desk, a gesture of impatience. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler, opens the book, and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description, a risky move that highlights his desperation for answers. As he tears, he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped, a trick he learned from years of discreet operations. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves that speak of a lingering drought, and narrower roads that wind through the rural expanse, Gittes parks at the edge of the field. He is hefted half off the ground by two younger Farmers who spin him around, going through his clothes, tossing his wallet, his silver cigarette case, a luxury item from his days in the city, etc. Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet, with his back to the Red Faced Farmer, a man known for his fiery temper, leaning against the back of his car, breathing heavily. The Crippled Farmer, whose leg was injured in a tractor accident years ago, pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch, causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The paper's on the ground, and he picks it up. The Big Farmer, towering and imposing, takes a swing at Gittes, who kicks him squarely in the nuts, knees him in the jaw after he's doubled up, and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head, knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt. Gittes is staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the farmers, a makeshift holding area, with his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and the dog present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a huge mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing, the silence loaded with unspoken conflict. Evelyn, a woman of calm demeanor known for her loyalty, is driving, and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case, takes one, and offers one to Evelyn, who refuses. It's almost evening, the sky casting an orange glow. He pulls out the obituary column he'd folded up earlier in the day, a crucial piece of his investigation.

test_cases.name: Addition (~50%)
test_cases.description: The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume opening it. It is huge and there is a lot to go through and the print itself makes him squint. The book shows TRACT LOT PARCEL and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda etc'. These descriptions are old and faded but in the owners' column there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners. The Clerk turns sharply around and Gittes looks a little surprised. The exasperated Clerk reaches around rummages and slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler opens the book and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler looks toward the clerks then swiftly rips down the page tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As he tears he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat parched and drying groves and narrower roads. Gittes parks at the edge of the field. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. He is hefted half off the ground by two younger Farmers who spin him around going through his clothes tossing his wallet his silver cigarette case etc. Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet with his back to the Red Faced Farmer leaning against the back of his car breathing heavily. The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer. The paper's on the ground and he picks it up. The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes who kicks him squarely in the nuts knees him in the jaw after he is doubled up and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt. Gittes is staring down while lying in the screenedin porch of the farmers with his wife the Red Faced Farmer the Big Farmer and the dog present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose a huge mouse on his cheek and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn is driving and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case takes one and offers one to Evelyn who refuses. It is almost evening. He pulls out the obituary column he would folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume opening it. It is huge and there is a lot to go through and the print itself makes him squint. The book shows TRACT LOT PARCEL and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda etc'. These descriptions are old and faded but in the owners' column there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners. The Clerk turns sharply around and Gittes looks a little surprised. The exasperated Clerk reaches around rummages and slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler opens the book and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler looks toward the clerks then swiftly rips down the page tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As he tears he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat parched and drying groves and narrower roads. Gittes parks at the edge of the field. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Gittes is staring down while lying in the screenedin porch of the farmers with his wife the Red Faced Farmer the Big Farmer and the dog present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose a huge mouse on his cheek and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn is driving and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case takes one and offers one to Evelyn who refuses. It is almost evening. test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume opening it. It is huge and there is a lot to go through and the print itself makes him squint. Evelyn is driving and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case takes one and offers one to Evelyn who refuses. It is almost evening. He pulls out the obituary column he would folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The Dog turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume, opening it. It's huge and there's a lot to go through, and the print itself makes the cat squint. The book shows TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded, but in the owners' column, there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners. The Dog turns sharply around, and the Bird looks a little surprised. The exasperated Dog reaches around, rummages, and slaps a ruler on the desk. The Bird goes back to the stacks with the ruler, opens the book, and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, the Bird places the ruler, looks toward the dogs, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As the Bird tears, the Bird either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves, and narrower roads, the Bird parks at the edge of the field. The Bird is hefted half off the ground by two younger Elephants who spin the Bird around, going through the Bird's clothes, tossing the Bird's wallet, the Bird's silver cigarette case, etc. The Bird is badly banged up and half out on the Bird's feet, with the Bird's back to the Blue Whale, leaning against the back of the Bird's car, breathing heavily. The Mouse pokes the Bird rudely in the back with the Mouse's crutch, causing the Bird to turn sharply and look up at the Blue Whale. The paper's on the ground, and the Blue Whale picks it up. The Rhino takes a swing at the Bird, who kicks the Rhino squarely in the nuts, knees the Rhino in the jaw after the Rhino's doubled up, and hits the Rhino solidly. The Mouse takes careful aim and brings the Mouse's crutch down on the back of the Bird's head, knocking the Bird to the ground where the Bird lies still beside the Rhino who is writhing in agony in the dirt. The Bird is staring down while lying in the screened-in porch of the elephants, with the Bird's wife, the Blue Whale, the Rhino, and the dog present. The Bird has dried blood down the side of the Bird's face from the Bird's nose, a huge mouse on the Bird's cheek, and the Bird's clothes are torn in a couple of spots. The Bird looks out and says nothing. The Kangaroo is driving, and the Bird pulls out the Bird's cigarette case, takes one, and offers one to the Kangaroo, who refuses. It's almost evening. The Bird pulls out the obituary column the Bird had folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the southwest coast album, opening it. It's enormous and there's a lot to review, and the script itself makes him squint. The booklet shows PATH, UNIT, PLOT, and even a DIMENSIONS AND ANGLES designation where the description of the land unit is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 steps to Rio Blanco, thence 7000 steps to Sierra Azul, etc.' These descriptions are ancient and faded, but in the proprietors' column, there are numerous freshly written names pasted over the previous proprietors. The Clerk turns sharply around, and Gittes looks a little surprised. The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, and slaps a stapler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the shelves with the stapler, opens the booklet, and places the stapler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the PROPRIETOR column, he places the stapler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the proprietor's name and property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped. Amidst a hall of shimmering light and haze, cracked and drying orchards, and narrower tracks, Gittes parks at the edge of the pasture. He is hefted half off the ground by two younger Ranchers who spin him around, going through his clothes, tossing his money clip, his bronze lighter, etc. Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet, with his back to the Sunburned Rancher, leaning against the back of his car, breathing heavily. The Limping Rancher pokes him rudely in the back with his cane, causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Sunburned Rancher. The paper's on the ground, and he picks it up. The Tall Rancher takes a swing at Gittes, who kicks him squarely in the shin, knees him in the jaw after he's doubled up, and hits him solidly. The Limping Rancher takes careful aim and brings his cane down on the back of Gittes' head, knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Tall Rancher who is writhing in agony in the dirt. Gittes is staring down while lying in the sunroom of the ranchers, with his wife, the Sunburned Rancher, the Tall Rancher, and the cat present. He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a huge mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots. He looks out and says nothing. Evelyn is driving, and Gittes pulls out his lighter, takes one, and offers one to Evelyn, who refuses. It's almost evening. He pulls out the events column he'd folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Clerk stumbles forward unexpectedly and flips open the northwest valley volume, examining it. It's huge and there's a lot to understand, and the print itself makes him blink. The book explains TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved, with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded, but in the owners' column, there are numerous freshly inked names scrawled over the prior owners. The Clerk shifts suddenly around, and Gittes looks a little startled. The frustrated Clerk reaches forward, fumbles, and drops a ruler on the desk. Gittes returns to the stacks with the ruler, shuts the book, and holds the ruler not horizontally but vertically. Beside the OWNER column, he taps the ruler, glances toward the clerks, then subtly folds up the page, removing a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As he folds, he either sneezes or laughs to conceal the noise of the paper being folded. Amongst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves, and narrower roads, Gittes stops at the edge of the field. He is lifted half off the ground by two younger Farmers who flip him around, inspecting his clothes, dropping his wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. Gittes is slightly bruised and half upright on his feet, with his back to the Red Faced Farmer, leaning against the back of his car, exhaling heavily. The Crippled Farmer nudges him rudely in the back with his crutch, causing Gittes to pivot sharply and glance up at the Red Faced Farmer. The paper's on the ground, and he retrieves it. The Big Farmer attempts a punch at Gittes, who dodges him squarely in the nuts, elbows him in the jaw after he's doubled up, and shoves him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and taps his crutch on the back of Gittes' head, causing him to the ground where he lies motionless beside the Big Farmer who is squirming in pain in the dirt. Gittes is gazing upward while lying in the screened-in porch of the farmers, with his wife, the Red Faced Farmer, the Big Farmer, and the dog present. He has dried mud down the side of his face from his nose, a huge bump on his cheek, and his clothes are frayed in a couple of spots. He looks in and says nothing. Evelyn is navigating, and Gittes takes out his cigarette case, selects one, and offers one to Evelyn, who declines. It's nearly evening. He takes out the obituary column he'd collected up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Librarian swivels away swiftly and pulls down the northeast mountain manuscript, opening it. It's enormous and there's a lot to sift through, and the font itself makes her squint. The tome displays SECTOR, BLOCK, SECTION, and even a CURVES AND ANGLES designation where the depiction of the territory section is lengthy and bewilderingly intricate, with descriptions like '5000 strides to Green River, thence 8000 strides to Pine Hill, etc.' These depictions are antiquated and faded, but in the keepers' section, there are numerous freshly printed labels pasted over the previous keepers. The Librarian pivots sharply around, and Wilson looks slightly taken aback. The frustrated Librarian reaches around, rummages, and slams a thermometer on the table. Wilson returns to the shelves with the thermometer, opens the tome, and places the thermometer not horizontally but vertically. Beside the KEEPER section, he places the thermometer, looks toward the librarians, then deftly rips down the folio, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the keeper's name and territory depiction. As he tears, he either sneezes or clears his throat to mask the noise of the paper being torn. Amidst a corridor of glimmering mist and warmth, barren and drying orchards, and narrower paths, Wilson parks at the border of the meadow. He is hoisted half off the ground by two younger Bakers who whirl him around, rifling through his apparel, tossing his billfold, his gold lighter case, etc. Wilson is severely battered and half out on his feet, with his back to the Flushed Baker, leaning against the rear of his truck, panting heavily. The Limping Baker jabs him rudely in the back with his cane, prompting Wilson to turn abruptly and glance up at the Flushed Baker. The parchment's on the ground, and he picks it up. The Burly Baker takes a swing at Wilson, who kicks him squarely in the shins, knees him in the chin after he's doubled over, and punches him firmly. The Limping Baker aims carefully and brings his cane down on the back of Wilson's head, knocking him to the soil where he lies motionless beside the Burly Baker who is twisting in torment in the dust. Wilson is gazing down while lying in the screened-in terrace of the bakers, with his partner, the Flushed Baker, the Burly Baker, and the cat present. He has dried rust down the side of his forehead from his mouth, a large welt on his jaw, and his attire is shredded in a few areas. He gazes out and says nothing. Alice is steering, and Wilson pulls out his lighter case, takes one, and offers one to Alice, who declines. It's nearly dusk. He pulls out the memorial notices he'd folded up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Librarian whirls away abruptly and drags down the northeast canyon volume, flipping it open. It's enormous and there's a lot to sift through, and the font itself makes him blink. The tome displays TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the account of the land parcel is lengthy and hopelessly detailed, with descriptions like '6000 strides to Rio Seco, thence 7000 strides to Loma Linda, etc.' These accounts are ancient and blurred, but in the proprietors' column, there are countless newly typed names affixed over the previous proprietors. The Librarian spins briskly around, and Marlowe looks somewhat astonished. The frustrated Librarian reaches around, fishes, and smacks a compass on the counter. Marlowe wanders back to the archives with the compass, opens the tome, and places the compass not horizontally but vertically. Beside the PROPRIETOR column, he places the compass, glances toward the librarians, then swiftly rips down the sheet, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the proprietor's name and land account. As he rips, he either sneezes or hums to mask the sound of the paper being torn. Amidst a hall of flickering dust and warmth, thirsty and desiccating orchards, and narrower tracks, Marlowe stops at the edge of the meadow. He is lifted half off the ground by two younger Ranchers who twirl him around, inspecting his attire, discarding his wallet, his gold cigarette case, etc. Marlowe is badly roughed up and half out on his feet, with his back to the Sunburned Rancher, leaning against the rear of his car, inhaling heavily. The Lame Rancher jabs him rudely in the back with his cane, causing Marlowe to swivel sharply and gaze up at the Sunburned Rancher. The paper's on the dirt, and he collects it. The Burly Rancher takes a jab at Marlowe, who elbows him soundly in the stomach, knees him in the chin after he's hunched over, and punches him firmly. The Lame Rancher takes careful aim and brings his cane down on the back of Marlowe's head, dropping him to the earth where he lies motionless beside the Burly Rancher who is twitching in torment in the dust. Marlowe is peering down while lying in the screened-in porch of the ranchers, with his daughter, the Sunburned Rancher, the Burly Rancher, and the cat present. He has dried blood down the side of his cheek from his nose, a large bruise on his jaw, and his garments are ripped in a few places. He gazes out and remains silent. Katherine is steering, and Marlowe pulls out his cigarette case, plucks one, and extends one to Katherine, who declines. It's nearly nightfall. He unfolds the news column he'd creased up earlier in the day.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Clerk spins away abruptly and drags down the southwest canyon atlas, flipping it open. It's enormous, and there's a lot to sift through, and the script itself makes him blink rapidly. The atlas displays PLOT, PATCH, SECTION, and even a LIMITS AND TERRITORY marker where the narrative of the land patch is lengthy and hopelessly complex, with narratives like '6000 strides to Rio Seco, thence 7000 strides to Loma Linda, etc.' These narratives are ancient and dim, but in the proprietors' section, there are countless newly printed labels glued over the previous proprietors. The Clerk pivots sharply around, and Gittes appears slightly startled. The frustrated Clerk stretches around, fumbles, and slams a compass on the counter. Gittes retreats to the aisles with the compass, flips the atlas, and positions the compass not vertically but in a diagonal. Next to the PROPRIETOR section, he places the compass, glances toward the clerks, then swiftly slices across the page, stripping out a strip about two inches wide containing the proprietor's title and land narrative. As he slices, he either sneezes or clears his throat to mask the noise of the paper being sliced. Amidst a corridor of flickering mist and breeze, thirsty and brittle orchards, and slimmer trails, Gittes halts at the fringe of the yard. He is hoisted half off the earth by two younger Shepherds who twirl him around, rummaging through his garments, tossing his pouch, his golden pen case, etc. Gittes is severely roughed up and half dazed on his feet, with his back to the Red Faced Shepherd, leaning against the rear of his vehicle, panting heavily. The Lame Shepherd jabs him rudely in the back with his cane, causing Gittes to rotate sharply and gaze up at the Red Faced Shepherd. The paper's on the earth, and he lifts it. The Large Shepherd takes a jab at Gittes, who nudges him squarely in the shins, elbows him in the chin after he's doubled over, and taps him firmly. The Lame Shepherd takes deliberate aim and crashes his cane down on the rear of Gittes' head, sending him to the earth where he rests quietly beside the Large Shepherd who is squirming in discomfort in the dust. Gittes is gazing down while lying in the screened-in veranda of the shepherds, with his spouse, the Red Faced Shepherd, the Large Shepherd, and the cat present. He has dried paint down the side of his face from his ear, a massive welt on his forehead, and his garments are shredded in a couple of spots. He gazes out and utters nothing. Evelyn is steering, and Gittes draws out his pen case, extracts one, and offers one to Evelyn, who declines. It's nearly dusk. He extracts the classified section he'd crumpled up earlier in the morning.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Astronaut turns around unexpectedly and lifts up the southeastern canyon notebook, flipping it open. It's tiny and there's little to sift through, and the drawings themselves make her giggle. The leaflet displays FOREST, LAKE, RIDGE, and even a KNOLLS AND HIGHLANDS label where the account of the water formation is brief and easily explained, with phrases like '4000 hops to Lake Shiny, thereafter 5000 hops to Hill Dull, etc.' These accounts are new and bright, but in the residents' section, there are several hastily penned dates scribbled over the former residents. The Astronaut pivots smoothly, and Mabel seems somewhat amused. The irritated Astronaut reaches outward, searches, and taps a spoon on the table. Mabel returns to the racks with the spoon, flips open the leaflet, and places the spoon not vertically but diagonally. Next to the RESIDENT section, she places the spoon, glances toward the astronauts, then stealthily pulls up the sheet, tearing off a fragment about one inch broad featuring the resident's date and aquatic account. As she pulls, she either giggles or whispers to cover the rustle of the sheet being pulled. Among a field of glistening mist and chill, frozen and flourishing forests, and broader pathways, Mabel stops at the center of the meadow. She is lifted fully off the path by three older Poets who twirl her around, examining her shoes, flipping her notebook, her gold pen holder, etc. Mabel is lightly scratched and fully out on her hands, with her front to the Red Haired Poet, leaning upon the side of her scooter, chuckling softly. The Curious Poet nudges her gently in the hip with his cane, causing Mabel to swivel slowly and look over at the Red Haired Poet. The leaflet's on the path, and she gathers it up. The Tall Poet takes a leap at Mabel, who nudges him lightly in the shins, elbows him in the shoulder after he's spun around, and grabs him gently. The Curious Poet takes precise aim and drops his cane on the front of Mabel's hand, sending her to the pathway where she rests quietly beside the Tall Poet who is smiling gracefully on the grass. Mabel is staring up while resting in the open-air pavilion of the poets, with her partner, the Red Haired Poet, the Tall Poet, and the lion present. She has dried ink down the side of her neck from her chin, a tiny bruise on her arm, and her shoes are scuffed in a few spots. She gazes inward and says everything. Eliza is sailing, and Mabel takes out her pen holder, holds one, and presents one to Eliza, who declines. It's nearly morning. She takes out the comic strip she'd clipped up previously in the week.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The Clerk retrieves the northwest valley volume, filled with complex and faded land parcel descriptions. Freshly typed names replace old ones in the owner's column. The Clerk, exasperated, hands Gittes a ruler. Gittes discreetly tears a strip from the page containing owner details, masking the noise with a cough. In a parched landscape, Gittes parks near a field and is ambushed by two younger Farmers who search him, hurling his belongings. Dazed and battered, Gittes leans against his car. A Crippled Farmer rudely prods him, prompting a confrontation with the Red Faced Farmer. Gittes kicks and knees the Big Farmer, but the Crippled Farmer knocks him down with a crutch. Later, Gittes lies battered on a porch with other Farmers and a dog. He remains silent, observing his surroundings. Evelyn drives as Gittes lights a cigarette and checks an obituary column he kept earlier.

surprised These descriptions are old and faded but in the owners' column there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners The book shows TRACT LOT PARCEL and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda etc' It is huge and there is a lot to go through and the print itself makes him squint The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume opening it

test_cases.name: Jumble Segments Order
test_cases.description: The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head knocking him to the ground where he lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes who kicks him squarely in the nuts knees him in the jaw after he is doubled up and hits him solidly The book shows TRACT LOT PARCEL and even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved with descriptions like '6000 paces to Rio Seco thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda etc' The paper's on the ground and he picks it up The exasperated Clerk reaches around rummages and slaps a ruler on the desk The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch causing Gittes to turn sharply and look up at the Red Faced Farmer Gittes is staring down while lying in the screenedin porch of the farmers with his wife the Red Faced Farmer the Big Farmer and the dog present Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet with his back to the Red Faced Farmer leaning against the back of his car breathing heavily He pulls out the obituary column he would folded up earlier in the day Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler opens the book and places the ruler not horizontally but vertically Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat parched and drying groves and narrower roads It is huge and there is a lot to go through and the print itself makes him squint He looks out and says nothing He is hefted half off the ground by two younger Farmers who spin him around going through his clothes tossing his wallet his silver cigarette case etc Gittes parks at the edge of the field It is almost evening The Clerk turns sharply around and Gittes looks a little surprised He has dried blood down the side of his face from his nose a huge mouse on his cheek and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler looks toward the clerks then swiftly rips down the page tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description As he tears he either sniffles or coughs to cover the sound of the paper being ripped The Clerk turns away abruptly and hauls down the northwest valley volume opening it These descriptions are old and faded but in the owners' column there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners Evelyn is driving and Gittes pulls out his cigarette case takes one and offers one to Evelyn who refuses
